### `Esquisse`

#### Download

Download a copy of everything you need to follow along the example^[You will have to unzip this file. If you are unfamiliar with this process, please check the [Unzipping files](/resource/unzipping/) section under Resources for assistance]
```{r echo=FALSE,eval=TRUE,message=FALSE,purl=FALSE}
loc <- here::here("static", "scripts",  "EDP613Esquisse.zip")

downloadthis::download_file(
  path = loc,
  output_name = "Esquisse example",
  button_label = "Download",
  button_type = "default",
  has_icon = TRUE,
  icon = "fa fa-save",
  class = "hvr-sweep-to-left"
  )
```

#### Description
If you would like to explore `ggplot2` using a more drag and drop approach, try the R package `esquisse`

To get it, open up RStudio and run
```{r eval=FALSE}
install.packages("esquisse", dependencies = TRUE)
```

and also install the example data set [palmerpenguins](https://allisonhorst.github.io/palmerpenguins/articles/intro.html){target="_blank"} by
```{r eval=FALSE}
install.packages("palmerpenguins", dependencies = TRUE)
```

If prompted, you do not have to restart RStudio though it can't hurt. After both install, run

```{r eval=FALSE}
esquisse::esquisser(palmerpenguins::penguins)
```

<center>
![esquisse with palmerpenguins](/gifs/esquisse1.gif){width=85%}
</center>
If you want to use your own data set, run the following
```{r eval=FALSE}
esquisse::esquisser()
```

<center>
![esquisse with palmerpenguins](/gifs/esquisse2.gif){width=85%}
</center>
